subject: RE: [junit] Threshholds for (J)Unit Testing
msgSnippet: ... Jutta Eckstein, who is experienced in team sizes around a hundred of developers, is known for saying that *especiall* for larger teams she finds Agile
messageBody:
junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> [Hopefully, this will be another interesting thread for
> discussion,...] I'm curious about threshholds for valuable
> (J)Unit Testing. There has been a lot of discussion of 100
> errors 'suddenly' showing up, and most seem to think this to
> be a rare thing,...which led me and others to question the
> size of the development group or code base. So, my first
> question, is what is a 'development team size' threshhold for
> meaningful Unit Testing? At what point do you think there
> are too many cooks in the kitchen,...or is there no
> threshhold, assuming that your team sticks to the tenets of
> TDD/XP/Agile/'general good coding practices'?

Jutta Eckstein, who is experienced in team sizes around a hundred of
developers, is known for saying that *especiall* for larger teams she finds
Agile practices to be vital. I haven't read her book yet, but it seems to
also contain some advice on testing:
http://www.jeckstein.de/agilebook/index.html

> Additionally,
> my team has been struggling with maintaining our tests at
> green bar, so my second question is what is a 'code size
> (number of classes)' threshhold for meaningful Unit Testing?

The larger the code base, the more important automated focussed tests seem
to be to me.

> We have upwards of 10 developers working on ~1500 classes.
> Our tests are a pain to maintain

What specific pain(s) are you experiencing? Can you give examples? Why do
you think it has something to do with the size of the project?

> - takes too long to run
> completely in Eclipse before checking in;

There are too solutions here:

- don't always run them all,
- speed them up

Not having them doesn't look like a valid option to me, unless the system
doesn't have to work (which would make me wonder why you develop it at all).

> takes ~6 hours to run

Why are they taking that long?

> and report the nightlybuild (includes coverage testing);

How much time is coverage testing consuming? What value does it have for
you?

> we're nowhere near green bar, so recognizing when there is
> something new (from yesterday) is near impossible, and
> possibly impractical (in a 40 hour work week). I'm not
> necessarily looking for any answers,...but maybe someone has
> some insight - has been there before - or will just commisserate with
> me. :)

We have around half a million lines of code (don't know the number of
classes), but only 4500 unit tests (it's legacy code, we are adding tests
slowly). The full test suite takes several minutes to run, a full build
roughly an hour. The full build is executed continuously by a Cruise Control
server.

Before committing, I typically run only the suites of modules I have changes
in (the code is distributed over 80+ modules). The suite for a module
typically only takes a couple of seconds to run. (I hope the continuous
testing plugin will soon work with the lates stable build of Eclipse again.)

The tests that take the most amount of time are those for parsing XML. I
guess if it would become a problem, we probably could improve those.

Hope this helps giving you some context and ideas...

Take care, Ilja
